text: Afghanistan–Poland relations refers to the official relations between Afghanistan and Poland. Afghanistan has an embassy in Warsaw, and Poland has an embassy in Kabul. ==History== Embassy of Afghanistan in Warsaw Modern relations between Afghanistan and Poland dated back from 20th century, when King Amanullah Khan visited Poland at 1928 and received a warm welcome from the Polish Government.https://www.academia.edu/816644/A_Historic_Visit_of_Amanullah_the_King_of_Afghanistan_in_Poland_29_April_2_May_1928_in_Afghanica._The_Afghanistan_Studies_Newsletter_Institute_of_Oriental_Philo- logy_Jagiellonian_University_nos_11-13_vol._6_7_Sept._1992_March- Sept.1993_p._14-16 This subsequently gave Afghanistan and Poland its full diplomatic relations. However, relations were later severed after the World War II and later Cold War, in which both had little to no formal connection. At 1980s, during the Soviet–Afghan War, Poland as part of communist Eastern Bloc sided with the Soviet Union, but on the same time, growing Solidarity movement in Poland and strong anti-Soviet resistance led by Ahmad Shah Massoud were instrumental on causing the collapse of the communist world and the fall of USSR. Poles showed great support and solidarity toward Afghans against the USSR.https://intmassmedia.com/2017/02/14/the-polish-mujahideen/ ==Modern== At 1990s, Poland showed support to Ahmad Shah Massoud-led Northern Alliance to fight the Taliban. Shah Massoud also had an interview with a number of Poles, including Piotr Balcerowicz, the last to give interview to him before his death.http://www.global-geneva.com/last-known-interview-with-afghanistans- ahmad-shah-massoud/ Polish intelligence led by Alexander Makowski, assisted by anti-Taliban militias in Afghanistan, also helped discovering the existence of Osama Bin Laden and had urged the CIA to kill him at 1999, but the CIA rejected and thus, had missed the chance. The failed attempt was believed to had played a role leading to September 11 attacks by Bin Laden to the U.S. to growing anti-Western sentiment in Muslim world, which Makowski contributed to the missed an opportunity to eliminate Bin Laden's threat at 1999.https://www.mcclatchydc.com/news/nation-world/world/article24735439.html Poland also contributed troops to Afghanistan in the subsequent Afghan War after the collapse of Taliban rule as part of NATO mission to the country.https://brukselanato.msz.gov.pl/en/poland_in_nato/polish_commitment_to_operations_and_missions/ The Poles were able to win supports from Afghan locals, but it was hampered by American futile efforts in the war.https://www.theguardian.com/world/blog/2009/mar/06/polish-troops- afghanistan-ghazni However, due to the cost of the war, sometimes it was referred as Poland's "Vietnam Syndrome" because of incidents like Nangar Khel incident.https://foreignpolicy.com/2011/07/07/polands-vietnam-syndrome-in- afghanistan/ ==See also== *Nangar Khel incident ==References== ==External links== *Embassy of the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan in Warsaw *Embassy of the Republic of Poland in Kabul Poland Category:Bilateral relations of Poland
